OBITUARY ON THE LATE
PRESIDENT YUSOF BIN ISHAK


2.33 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Govindasamy, Sir, I am sure Members will join me in formally recording our sorrow at the death of our late President, Yusof bin Ishak Al-haj. He has become an institution over the past 11 years. He visited this House on so many occasions at the opening of each new session.

    I last spoke, in this House, of him and his gracious lady, when moving his re-election as Head of State in November 1967 for a third term. Shortly afterwards he was to fall ill. We did not then know how grave the illness was. During a sea voyage from Singapore to Australia in April 1968, the rhythm of his heart beat was upset and he had to be flown to Melbourne for treatment. We were grateful to the Australian Government, and the doctors and nurses in Melbourne who treated him.

    The prognosis of the Australian specialists was not encouraging. But, with skill and devotion, our doctors and nurses who took care of him, stretched what could have been a matter of a few months into 2 1/2 years. Their professional competence made this possible.

Column: 375



    I first came to know the late President early in 1951. He had come to seek my advice over an Utusan Melayu editor who was detained under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance. He was naturally well-mannered. Over the years, I got to know him as a deeply religious man, but one who did not allow his religion to hinder his relationship with non-Muslims, whether they were Christians, Hindus, Buddhists, Confucians, or atheists.

    He stood for our multi-racial policies. A recent speech he made to start off the fund for a monument to the early pioneers of Singapore was one which could only have been made by a person who believed in our multi-racial approach to solving the problems of our multi-racial society. At the same time, he was keen that in this multi-racial milieu, our Singapore Malays should break out from the bounds of customs which were preventing them from making the same progress as the other communities. He believed in policies to modernise our society, including our Malays. He believed that all men should be equal, or at least given equal opportunities to advance themselves through their own effort.

    I remember him as the man I spoke of in the motion for his re-election in November 1967. The long illness over nearly three years reduced him slowly to an invalid. It was painful and sad to watch him go down little by little after each relapse of his cardiac and respiratory problems.

    The burden was heaviest on his wife and children. As his condition deteriorated, his usually composed demeanour was affected. He was beset by anxieties.

    I saw him last on Sunday night, 22nd November, at 9.30 p.m, at the General Hospital. I had spoken to him on Saturday, 21st November, over the telephone. He told me not to see him until his attack of herpes, or shingles, was over. He sounded in greater pain than usual. The next day, Sunday afternoon, he had a heart

Column: 376

failure. He was put into an oxygen tent at the General Hospital. He must have known that the end was near. After a while, when the doctor had given an injection to resuscitate him, he came out of his plastic oxygen tent. He insisted on shaking hands with the doctors and nurses who had looked after him, and with me. I left after 20 minutes. The next morning, I was informed of his death.

    May I formally, Mr Govindasamy. Sir, ask that this House join me in sending the widow and his children our deep sympathies. Their loss must be greater than ours.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: As a mark of respect to the late President, I propose to suspend this sitting and I shall take the Chair again at 2.45 p.m.

CIVIL LIST AND PENSION
(AMENDMENT) BILL
First Reading


    The Prime Minister: Mr Govindasamy, Sir, I have the Acting President's recommendation to proceed with this Bill. Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled "An Act to amend the Civil List and Pension Act, 1970 (No. 10 of 1970)".

    Bill read the First time.
Second Reading


    Mr N. Govindasamy: Second Reading, what day?

    The Prime Minister: Now, Sir,I lay upon the Table a Certificate of Urgency signed by the Acting President in respect of the Civil List and Pension (Amendment) Bill.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: The Certificate is in order. Have typed or printed copies of the Bill been circulated to Members?

    The Prime Minister: They have been circulated, Sir.

Column: 377



    Mr Govindasamy, Sir, when the Civil List and Pension Bill was taken through Parliament earlier this year, the doctors who were treating the late President were optimistic that he might be able to serve his full term before retirement. But it was not to be.

    Had he retired at the time of his death, the late President would have been entitled to a pension of $ 17.466 per year, or $1,455 per month. As he was 60 years of age, he could have taken a gratuity of $72,777 (one-third of his full pension x 12 ½ years), together with a reduced pension of $970 per month. This formula for computation applies to all Ministerial pensions.

    The late President left behind a widow and three children, the youngest of whom is 18. Under the present law, Puan Noor Aishah will only be entitled to a gratuity. This could not have been more than the gratuity the late President would have been entitled to. She is only in the second half of her thirties and so has a considerable life expectancy. My colleagues and I decided that we should amend the Civil List and Pension Act for her special circumstances, without making it a precedent for the future.

    By this amending Bill, we shall provide her with a pension of $2,000 per month for life. As in all pensions to widows, it will cease in the event of re-marriage. There will be a further $500 per month for her children, until the youngest one has reached 21, or on her marriage if it is before 21.

    As their house has not yet been built on her piece of land, we have made available to her a government bungalow she has chosen from a number which were suitable. She will pay one-quarter of the economic rent of the house for a period of three years. During this time her own house could be built.

    In the declining years of the late President, she carried more of the social responsibilities of his office. I am sure the House will be with my colleagues and me in wanting to make these provisions for her and her children. This amending Bill will give her more

Column: 378

than what the late President himself would have been entitled to. But there are special reasons why we feel justified in seeking to make the necessary provisions set out in the Bill.

    Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [The Prime Minister].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

ELECTION OF PRESIDENT OF

REPUBLIC OF SINGAPORE


2.54 p.m.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Govindasamy, Sir, I beg to move,

    That this Parliament, in accordance with Article 1 of the Constitution, elects Dr Benjamin Henry SHEARES as President of Singapore.

    Since April 1968 my colleagues in the Cabinet and I have been conscious of the possibility of having to call upon one of our citizens, at short notice, to undertake the duties of President. It was a deliberation spread over 2½ years. After the death of the late President, we decided to invite Dr Benjamin Sheares to undertake this office.

    He is a doctor, eminent in his own specialty. By disposition courteous, by nature kind, he has done a great deal for the College of Medicine, and is largely responsible for the high standards of our gynaecologists, nearly all of whom he taught. After he retired in 1960, he went into private practice. However, he continued to help in many fields connected with his expertise. He has given generously of his time to public duties, like the Family Planning Association. As Chairman of the Medical Specialties Board, he was helping to decide on which medical specialties Singapore should concentrate her resources. He had to recommend which department had outstanding

Column: 379

specialists, so that the most modern equipment and facilities could be provided for the exercise of their talent, what special support in nurses, anaesthetists, radiographers, cardiographers, and specialised workers we must train to support these specialists in the use of the latest equipment.

    After he accepted the Government's offer to be nominated as President, I explained to Dr Sheares that he would have to undertake his duties as from the 2nd of January, 1971. In less than a fortnight he will be receiving the Heads of various Commonwealth delegations who will be arriving for the Conference. His first reaction was to ask for the curriculum vitae of the leaders of these delegations, and a note on the countries they represent, their history, their political, economic and social systems. He wanted to know about the men he will be meeting and the nature of the countries they represented. Although he has not been experienced in the political or diplomatic field, his readiness to bring a disciplined intellect to bear on to a new field augurs well for Singapore. I am confident that he will develop a grasp and understanding of persons and peoples, of associations and communities, of nations and their leaders, their national aspirations and individual ambitions. It will make what could be a perfunctory duty into an interesting office, more of a challenge than a chore.

    The duties of President require not only distinction and ability, but integrity and understanding. He brings deep qualities to the office of President. More than that, he is modest and friendly, by nature and habit.

    His wife, Mrs Sheares, speaks Chinese, English and some Malay. She can lend support to the President in his social duties.

    My colleagues and I commend Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares to the House for election as President. At 63, he enjoys good health, despite a major operation five years ago. Here is a man of outstanding ability. I am sure he

Column: 380

will grow with the office, and discharge it with dignity and distinction.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

2.59 p.m.

    Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap (Geylang Serai)(In Malay): Mr Govindasamy, Sir, I rise to support the motion moved by the Prime Minister.

    The election of Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares to the high office of President is indeed appropriate. Dr Sheares will no doubt prove himself a capable person to carry out the functions and duties of Head of State, for not only is he a person of high academic eminence and attainment, but he is also a person with wide experience, a record of service to the public, and has close links with the people. There is no doubt that with such a background and experience as he possesses, he will be able to discharge the duties entrusted to him as Head of State of the Republic of Singapore with poise and grace.

    Sir, I beg to support the motion.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon (Tiong Bahru)(In Mandarin): Sir, ever since the demise 0 the late President Yusof, the office of the Head of State of our Republic of two million people has been vacant and the question of the new candidate for the presidency has become a topic of the people and the subject of speculation in various quarters. Indeed, in the same way as a group of dragons cannot go without a leader, no country can go without a Head of State, and it has become our first task today to decide on the question of who shall succeed the late President Yusof.

    As we all know, the office of President in our Republic is somewhat different from that of other countries. He represents, both here and abroad, our Republic and is a symbol of the dignity and honour of our people. He is also a symbol of the unity and the values of our Republic. In these turbulent times and in the course of nation building and development, he will have

Column: 381

an important role to perform. Therefore, the office of President cannot be overlooked. It is indeed a very difficult task to choose a suitable person for this post. He should be a person of learning, good conduct and high reputation. He should indeed be a 1eader acceptable both here and abroad. To a big country with a lot of people the choice of such a person presents no difficulty. But to Singapore, it is not easy to make such a choice.

    Having heard the Prime Minister and read the curriculum vitae published in the newspapers recently, I firmly believe that Dr Sheares is the best and the most suitable choice, because he has all the attributes and qualities required for this high office. He was born and bred in Singapore and has been brought up as an outstanding figure in our Republic. By his own efforts he has made his name known internationally and has brought great honour to Singapore. He has also a distinguished record of service to our country and our people. He reflects in his own life the finest qualities and the best spirit of Singapore. These are dedication to the country, devotion to society, a love of people, contribution to human welfare, and a profound understanding of the characteristics of our multi-racial country.

    We fully support the recommendation by the Prime Minister of Dr Sheares to this high office. It is our hope that he will, in the same kindly spirit of a physician and by his own virtues, carry .on from where our late President has left off, so that our new and young Republic will be able to set a shining example in turbulent Southeast Asia and make her name felt throughout the world. We pledge our full support and co-operation.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson)(In Tamil): Sir, I wholeheartedly endorse the remarks of the Prime Minister. I have had the opportunity of meeting Dr Sheares on many occasions when he was working in the Outram Road General Hospital and the Kandang Kerbau Maternity Hospital. I was then

Column: 382

working in the postal services. I have known him as a friendly, approachable and understanding person who shows great concern for other people's problems.

    As a young Republic, our country has been fortunate to have dynamic leadership. In the last decade we have made good progress in the economic and industrial fields, resulting in our people having the highest standard of living in this region. At this crucial stage of our progress, it is important that we have a President who can not only keep up with the pace of progress that we have achieved so far, but can also command the respect and confidence of our people. This honour is rightly bestowed upon Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares. Sir, I have great pleasure in supporting the Prime Minister's motion to elect him as our new President.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That this Parliament, in accordance with Article 1 of the Constitution, elects Dr Benjamin Henry SHEARES as President of Singapore.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS



3.06 p.m.
SCHOOL CADET CORPS MEMBERS
(Reduction of period of full-time national service)


    1. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister of Defence if he will consider reducing the period of full-time national service from two years to one and a half years for persons who have served three years in school cadet corps.

    The Minister of State of Defence (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister of Defence): Sir, the Member does not appreciate the difference between service in School Cadet Corps and full-time national service in the Armed Forces. Apart from differences in training systems, service in the Cadet Corps is purely voluntary. A schoolboy joining the Cadet Corps does so as part

Column: 383

of his extra-curricular activities and because he finds service in the Corps interesting and useful. He is better motivated than other boys and wants to set an example to them in serving the country.

    Those who have done well in the School Cadet Corps should qualify when doing national service for promotion to the officer grade, or at least to the NCO grade. They will then be doing two and a half years' service, not two years, much less one and a half years.

    To allow Cadet Corps service to count for national service purposes would introduce an element of self-seeking calculation which will undermine the whole spirit of the Cadet Corps.

Column: 383

CARTRIDGE-OPERATED
FASTENING TOOLS
(Regulations for possession and use)


    2. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour if he will take steps to control the importation, sale, possession and use of cartridge-operated fastening tools as they are dangerous tools and may also be used as lethal weapons.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Sir, records in the Ministry of Labour show that so far there has been only one report of a non-fatal accident involving the use of cartridge-operated fastening tools. For this reason the need for regulations on the importation, use or possession of these tools has not been felt so far. However, in view of the high injury potential of cartridge-operated fastening tools, consideration will be given to the introduction of special regulations for the possession and use of these tools.

POSTMEN
(Resignations)


    3. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Communications how

Column: 384

many postmen and assistant postmen resigned the service during the period January to November 1970, and the reasons for such resignations.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications (Mr Phua Bah Lee) (for the Minister for Communications): Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to answer.

    A total of 17 postmen and three assistant postmen resigned the service during the 11-month period under reference. Most of them had less than a year's service and left for alternative employment elsewhere.

    Recruitment action to fill the vacancies is in progress.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Can the Parliamentary Secretary say how many vacancies there are for postmen and assistant postmen at present?

    Mr Phua Bah Lee: At the moment there are 17 vacancies for postmen.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that some of these postmen are making only one delivery a day instead of two deIiveries?

    Mr Phua Bah Lee: It is not true, Sir. From the General Post Office, there are three deliveries a day. From sub post offices, there are normally two deliveries, a day.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: I was told the postmen are working more than eight hours a day without a meal break. Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware of that?

    Mr Phua Bah Lee: Sir, that is not true.

MULTI-STOREY FLATS
(Provision of letter-boxes on ground floor)


    4. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Communications if he will take steps to require that private letter-boxes are provided on the ground floor-for each flat in multi-storeyed private and Housing and Development Board flats.

Column: 385



    Mr Phua Bah Lee (for the Minister for Communications): Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to answer.

    Legislation is being prepared to provide for the compulsory installation of letter-boxes in all high-rise residential and office buildings, including Government buildings. The scheme will be implemented in stages under which developers or owners of buildings already completed or under construction will be given reasonable time to comply with the provisions of the new law.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, how many multi-storey buildings are there in which letter-boxes have been provided on the ground floor either in Housing Board flats or private flats?

    Mr Phua Bah Lee: Sir, at the moment there are five Housing Board estates having such letter-boxes, namely, St. Michael's Road Estate, Selegie House Estate, Bukit Ho Swee Estate, Toa Payoh Estate and Queenstown Neighbour 6.

TOA PAYOH
(Provision of more posting facilities)


    5. Mr Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Communications if he will consider putting up more post-boxes in Toa Payoh pending the construction of a post office there.

    Mr Phua Bah Lee (for the Minister for Communications): Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to answer.

    Toa Payoh has been provided with three posting boxes located as follows:

    (i) Junction of Lorong IA and Lorong 2:

    (ii) Junction of Lorong 3 and Lorong 4;

    (iii) Lorong 6 (near its junction with Toa Payoh East).

These posting boxes are so located that the nearest posting facilities can be reached within a half-mile distance.

    Pending the establishment of a proper post office in the estate by January or February 1971 (that is, in about a month's time), additional posting

Column: 386

facilities are also being presently provided by a mobile post office which calls at the car park opposite the junction of Lorong 4 and Toa Payoh Central daily, except Sundays and public holidays.

    The provision of more posting facilities is all the time being considered, and additional posting boxes will progressively be installed at suitable locations in the estate to meet the needs of the residents.

PRIMARY SCHOOL PUPILS
(Request to leave school or transfer out)


    6. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Education if he is aware that, in order to avoid poor school results in the Primary School Leaving Examination, some principals have asked pupils whose performances have been poor to leave school voluntarily or to seek transfer to another school; and what steps he has taken or proposes to take in the matter.

    The Minister of State for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng) (for the Minister for Education): Sir, my Minister has asked me to reply.

    My Ministry's regulations governing the retention and superannuation of pupils specifically provide that no pupil below the age of 16 can be asked to leave school unless he or she is guilty of persistent bad conduct.

    As for transfers, no pupil can be transferred from one school to another by principals except at the express request of parents. To date, my Ministry has received no complaints from parents that their children have been asked to leave school voluntarily or to seek a transfer because of their poor performance. Any such complaints will be duly investigated and, if substantiated, followed by appropriate disciplinary action.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Sir, I would like the Minister of State for Education to clarify two points. The first is about bad conduct. What is the criterion for bad conduct?

Column: 387



    Secondly, can the Minister of State say whether his Ministry will take strict measures to deal with complaints by parents of students to Members of Parliament at meet-the-people sessions?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, as regards the second point, I have just answered it in the last sentence of my answer to the original question. I said that any such complaints will be duly investigated and, if substantiated, followed by appropriate disciplinary action.

    On the question of what is the criterion for bad conduct, it must be persistent bad conduct. The pupils must first be warned and their parents notified, and if the pupils do not improve, then they will be asked to leave school.

And three of these barley seeds placed end to end constituted one inch. A yard was the distance from the tip of King Edgar's nose to the tip of the middle finger of his outstretched arm.
